Dear Lindar
I was very happy to get your letter yesterday, and before anything else, the
current address is ii,62 Castro, SF 9UllU (I|.l5) ij.31-88l4l.. Oh, and I use Joseph now,
not Joe. I was Joe for years, but after a while I felt it didn't fit, and Joey was
certainiy out of vogue and inappropriate, I mean, after all...I am 3Ui
Sort of creeps up on you, doesn't it? It just slips by so quickly, and you mellow as
it races by and things get more and more distant in the past, and then something comes
up, either a new experience which reminds you of something you've experienced, or a
situation arises, as with your kids, in which you are obliged to recall things that
have lain forgotten down there someplace, and it all comes back, and it's a good
feeling, at times.Sure, I'll tell you as much as you want to hear, and probably more
than that at times. You know how I love to run off at the mouth, and the yeara have
only made that tendency stronger, but with greater judgment and to people who are —
better chosen, because they show an interest. So let's start off with me.
The enclosed snapshot was taken at a,party at ny flat here in SF g3ven to celebrate
via a musicale(played by ny teacher, not me) the arrival of ny new two-manual harpsichord,^,
A clever friend of mine took it at precisely the moment when I was escplaining to somoene f... :•
that you don't hit it like a piano, but gently stroke the keys, because they pluck,
not strike, the strings. My hair was longer then thah I wearit now,, and there is now
a bit less of it than there was before, mainly becaise I wear it. shorter now, curly. -
I have noticed with the passage of time that I am destined to have a magnificent Victor- .
like forehead, the temple of my intellect, etc. I once thought of this as of the curse
of the Pazminos, that once you lost your hair, it was ̂ 1 over, etc. Well, I'm past '■
that now, not only because the forehead itself looks good, but also because I am told
by the young men I occasionally involve myself romantically with (move over, fellow
skeleton, this family closet is narrow) that it makes me look sexyj I don't know about
you, but my thirties so far, with a few exceptions, have been the best part of ry life.
What happened to Harvard? I got sick of it, andafter the first year the government
withdrew, not ray grant, but the entire program from which the fundscame, and I lost
interest. I worked teaching at a small college in Boston for 2 years to makeraoney and pay
phd tuition, but that got old quickly, and I started working as an editor at Houghton
Mfflin in Boston, fgn lang texts (if any. of this is old news, bear with me...i don't
remember when last I spoke/wrote with/to you), which was a lot of money(got me through
ly goodies stage of life) but which was like working for a bank. Finally went on vacation
and convention combination trip to SF, moved here four mths later. I'fy first job here was
in a pornographic bookstore, owned by a friend of mine, sitting behind the hblihte'rp'a
few hrs a week, all under the counter- T^is got to be a bore tooj after one day one gets
familiar with and saturated by the reading material (great cast of thousands, but the
plots are dull as shit) and the only thing left to do is watch the «?ustoraers, which is
fun. Then I got a job teaching English as a 2nd language to Spanish speakers in a federally
funded city administered program. That lasted two years, witnessed complete changes of
professional personnel(teachers) but strange permanence of local nepotistic (?) administra
tion, local latinos, and their brothers-in-law, you can fill in the lines between the dots.
Then I didn't work for months, had a deep and disastrous affair, contemplated suicide,
finally realized that that was no good because there isn't anybody around any more who can
give a decent eulogy, got a job (which I'm at now) in the mornings, mere clerical stuff.
I'm here i|. hrs, work generally one, write letters, read, listen to music, nap, etc. On
weekend nights I bus tables at a Hungarian restaurant owned by a friend, where I hope to
be made waiter, which I do, practice-training style) now two nights midweek. So what
happened to Harvard, to the PhD, to the academic career? It got old, and I decided that
imnt my time for myself and ly interests. I am fortunate in that I have only lyself to
csre about, worry over, feed, clothe and shelter, so why should I spend even one minute
doing something dreary (research for papers I don't care about-publish or perish.
work in an office and make lots bread-have no time to enjoy, or anything tiresome lie
that, especially when it s impossible to get teaching jobs. I do ly "things" and enjqy
whatever good things of life that come ray way, and tl^re are plenty. How do I live?
Boyally, I might even say qieenly, i|62 Castro is a nine room Victorian flat right in
the middle of the "gay" ghetto, near to everything I need in rty life, shopping, movies,
bars, stores, etc, all trolley (REAL TROLLEY CARS) and bus lines.I have 2 roommates,
one, one of my oldest and closets friends, anf the other a nice and ehh. unobtrusive
fellnw from upstate NY. The place is in try narae, costs 175 a rath(total), and is palatial.
The landlord, perhaps the last great man on earth, has paid for all the renovation of
this marvelous flat, which for decades suffered under the -Pontius Pilate of cheap enamel,
by the coatioad, ugly wallpaper, no inspiration, etc. Landlord, hereinafter referred to as
Art, said that it was worth the expense(deductible, too) to have the place fixed xp by
people who love their home, and he's tickled pink to have such good tenants. Hopes we stay
20years. I could ramble on endlessly, but I'll spare you that for the time(l ̂ go on)
and merely say that it's wonderful to have someone to pay for all your decorating ideas,
to enable you to let yair fancy fly freely, and be happy with the resiilt. The nicest part
is that the :^ent is more or less at a 19U7 level. One pays 175 for a studio and feels luclqjy,
So that s me of the past few years.
Family news first, then histojy. Dg&ais is thinking of marrying again, is in fact
engaged to some divorcee with kids he met in Rochester, where he has lived for over 12
years or so. He is now 32, Lolita is most anxious that he not make another mistake like

can take the consequences .^'3iain?a"X'ou'"'has'^ babv girlTjo"^ is many times a grandmother,

Dear Lindaj
So I write you ^nd you v/rmte me and I take an eternity to
answer. Fine situation, especially after I blow off about my
answering letters as sbon as they come. Guess I'm getting lazier.
Anyway, here goes another, and thanks for the snapshots, you
know, it's remarkable how much you resenble your mother at that
age; being the semi-official custodian of old family snapshots
lets one see physical resemblances as they develop/vanish with
time. I used to look like my father when j was very little, and
that vanished, the only remnants currently remaining being a
marked tendency to get freckles on my shoulders after every
summer's color-feast, and a red mustache...well, reddish at
the ends at any rate. He s been (bad two years now, and I get
sporadic letters from Minnie, the latest a month ago. She hasn't
been well at all physically, having just had some horrible-soundi
ng stomach/intestinal infection that required 5 transfusions,
she also had another heart attack a while back, poor woman. She
misses him terribly, she still lives where they did in Florida,
and goes and vislta her real children and the two foster kids
they adopted.
As for your question^, I'll answer them as I reread your
letter. Yes, Dennis is a photographer still, and,still living in
Rochester, A while back Lolita told me he was gojng to get
married again; she and Tony had some reservations, because the
girl/woman ms a widow with two kids and a whole mess of serious
back/spine trouble which would require surgery, but they decided
to let him make up his own mind without any advice or negative
reaction, A while later I heard that he had changed his mind.
Not only did he have so many toys...i think most of it is still
laying about the place on E 5'^th st, as Lolita writes that die an
tony are about to start cleaning out all t^is junk. He really was
spoiled as a kid; I remember thinking that he always got whatever
he wanted, too much, I remember once, when we were older, saying
soinething about that and how my childhood had some rather differs
nt aspects to it, how I had to work for all that and do the
whole thing about college by myself, etcetc.(I was being a bore
that day) and Lola said something like '^Thatds rightl? I wonder
whatever became of that cooky Bom-iie he wqs married to for a whil
she was really strange, looking back, (I'd never get an award fo
my typing, so bear with me.)
Joan and Bob are still together; as usual, he's in the midst
of landing some great new job that will bring in thousands, etc
etc, Joan just bears up. They live pretty well in southern cal,
in one of those endless subdivisions around LA. Leslie is married
and has two kids; they live in the Bergen Beach'"section, all of
which is now houses and shopping centers. Karen and Lvnn are both
divorced and have one kid; they live down'"'"WeFe""tbb. Lynn is
getting a degree in some sort of psychological counselling, she's
22 now, and really very together. Talking with her and Karen is
fun, because they're grown up people now, and the rela-tionship is
different. The otiser kids, all six of them, are boisterous,health

His parents live in the 4.rea too, which drives Joan crazy, as she

and.will be soon iBtiring from his Job as a security guard. They

ly Rd, That neighborhood is totally black now, and very bad, from
